item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds Roadmap—Mizutsune DLC Update & More
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/monster-hunter-wilds-roadmap-mizutsune-dlc-update-more/

Even though Monster Hunter Wilds isn’t out yet, its roadmap and future DLC content plans have been revealed. It’s not everything, granted, but this guide should give you an idea of what to expect in the beginning—including the arrival of Mizutsune.

It’s almost commonplace to let players know what future content is arriving before a game’s even launched. Capcom has copied this approach with Monster Hunter Wilds. The February 2025 Sony State of Play unveiled some ideas and plans from Capcom’s drawing board.

It’s not a monstrous amount of content announced, but enough to keep us all invested.

Monster Hunter Wilds Roadmap Explained

Capcom has revealed Monster Hunter Wilds is getting a lot of free content to support the game with patches, Quests, cosmetics, and fresh creatures to encounter.

Mizutsune

I’ll start with the headline maker itself: Mizutsune. First revealed via a PlayStation Blog post about Monster Hunter Wilds, Mizutsune is described as a “majestic monster.”

It’s described as having “dance-like attacks and bubbles to attack with a balance of beauty and brutality.” We’re unsure if it’s a general monster or requires more than a bunch of sticks and rocks to bring it down.

Event Quests & Cosmetics

Special Quests are being added, rewarding you with “in-game armor with special looks!” It remains to be seen what the Quests entail, but if Monster Hunter Wilds wasn’t already big enough, you need your busy hat on as there’s more work to be done!

Day One PS5 Pro Patch

The final key detail we know about Monster Hunter Wilds’ roadmap is a day-one update for PS5 Pro users. Capcom says: “Monster Hunter Wilds will be PS5 Pro enhanced via a day one patch, further enhancing immersion with ray tracing.”

When is Mizutsune Coming to Monster Hunter Wilds?

Mizutsune emerges in Monster Hunter Wilds in Spring 2025, giving you ample to prepare for the creature.

Capcom isn’t showing Mizutsune yet, but it’s clear the monster is a big deal—literally. Stay tuned for further updates on Mizutsune, where to find it, and how to trigger it in Monster Hunter Wilds.

Is it right for companies to announce DLC and roadmaps before launch? Is any negativity offset by declaring the content to be free on release? I’m mixed on the idea, but the transparency is commendable—as is the cost of Wilds’ announced content.

We have many other Monster Hunter Wilds guides including Pre-Order Bonuses and file size to the latest on the Beta Test.

item.title: BLAST.tv Austin CS2 Major Qualifiers Will be Played Entirely Online
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/blast-tv-austin-cs2-major-qualifiers-will-be-played-entirely-online/

The Major Regional Qualifiers for the BLAST Austin Major will be played entirely online, after consecutive years of offline qualifiers determining which Counter-Strike teams attend the Major. BLAST has revealed the full details of the MRQ’s, which are scheduled to take place in April.

BLAST.tv Austin Major Regional Qualifiers Information

Because of the decision to those the Major Regional Qualifiers online, the MRQs for the Americas and Asia will be split into sub-regions to prevent major ping issues. Valve added to their Major rulebook this year that Major qualifiers could be held online, so it’s not surprising to see tournament organizers take advantage.

In Europe, the top 10 teams according to the Valve Regional Standings will be invited directly to Stage 2 or Stage 3 of the Major. The next 16 ranked teams, starting with number 11, will compete in the European MRQ, in a Swiss stage featuring best-of-three matches for advancement and elimination. The top six from this Swiss stage will qualify for Stage 1 of the Major. The dates for the European MRQ are April 14-17.

The top five Americas teams will be invited directly to the Major. The Americas MRQ will consist of a North American MRQ and a South American MRQ. Each one is an eight-team GSL-style group stage, consisting of the top teams from each sub-region, excluding the top five Americas teams already invited. Three teams from each sub-region will qualify for Stage 1 of the Major. The dates for the Americas MRQs are April 15-17.

Only the top ranked team in Asia will be invited directly to the Major. The Asian MRQ will consist of three for each sub-region: China, Oceania/Southeast Asia, and Mongolia/Western Asia. Each region will utilize a four-team double elimination bracket. The sub-region with the highest-ranked invited team will send two teams to Stage 1, while the other sub-regions will send one team to Stage 1. The dates for the Asian MRQs are April 15-17.

What do you make of the decision to hold Major qualifiers online? Let us know down below and on the Insider Gaming forum.

item.title: EXCLUSIVE: Details Behind Funko Fusion Developer 10:10 Games’ Recent Layoffs
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/details-funko-fusion-developer-1010-games-recent-layoffs/

Funko Fusion developer 10:10 Games has recently undergone restructuring within the studio which includes some layoffs.

Insider Gaming has learned that 10:10 Games made changes with the last week as part of projects within the company wrapping up. We were told that the restructuring was being done to better meet the needs of current projects within the studio. What those projects are, however, remains unknown.

As far as the number of people let go, sources have indicated that it’s around 20 employees. 10:10 Games has yet to give clarification on the exact number of people who were laid off despite multiple requests.

Sources say that the company is assisting with those let go, but couldn’t verify whether that includes any sort of severance as of publishing.

Founded in 2021 by industry veterans Arthur Parsons and Traveller’s Tales founder Jon Burton, 10:10 Games is based in Warrington, United Kingdom. The studio released Funko Fusion, its first game, in September 2024. According to the latest public records and information from the studio’s website, 10:10 Games employed around 100 people before the layoffs.

Through the first seven weeks of 2025, the games industry has seen nearly 1,000 known jobs lost across 27 companies. Multiple companies have yet to make headcounts public, meaning t hat it’s likely the number is well over 1,000 at this point. In 2024, the industry saw over 16,000 estimated losses.
